Title: Every finite extension of a finite field is separable
Content:
I'm trying to prove that every finite extension of a finite field is separable. I found a solution on internet which says: Let $F$ be a finite field and $E$ be an extension of $F$ having  $p^n$
  elements. Then $E=F(\alpha)$, where $\alpha \in E$ and so
  $\alpha^{p^n} -\alpha=0$. This implies $\alpha$ is a separable
  element, and hence $F(\alpha)$ is a separable extension of F. I don't understand why $\alpha^{p^n} -\alpha=0$ and why $\alpha$ is a separable element, I need help. Thanks
AcceptedAnswer: Since any finite subgroup of the multiplicative group of any field is cyclic, if a field has $\,p^n\,$ elements, then its multiplicative group has $\,p^n-1\,$ elements, and thus for any non-zero element $\,\alpha\,$ in the field, $$\alpha^{p^n-1}=1\Longrightarrow \alpha^{p^n}=\alpha\Longleftrightarrow \alpha^{p^n}-\alpha=0$$ Note that the above equality is true also for the zero element in the field. Thus, any element in a field with $\,p^n\,$ elements is a root of $\,x^{p^n}-x\,$ , and this pol. is separable since its derivative is $\,p^nx^{p^n-1}-1=-1\neq 0\pmod p\,$

An algebraic extension E/F is separable if every element of E is separable over F, meaning the minimal polynomial of each element has distinct roots. But why does this imply α is separable? The minimal polynomial of α over F must have distinct roots. For finite fields, even though we have characteristic p, the Frobenius endomorphism (x ↦ x^p) is an automorphism. This means that the polynomial x^(p^n) - x splits into distinct linear factors in its splitting field, which is E itself. Each element of E is a root of this polynomial, and since x^(p^n) - x has no repeated roots (its derivative is -1, which has no roots, hence no multiple factors), all its roots are simple. Therefore, the minimal polynomial of α must divide x^(p^n) - x and hence must also have distinct roots. Thus, α is separable over F.
